blogList.author: Enes AYDOÄAN
blogList.title: Ä°lk Blog Denemesi
blogList.content:
Looking at the data and my comments to their portfolios I noticed patterns. Those patterns in turn led to a simple cutoff line being drawn.

You need to be THIS good to get hired.

There are levels of skill to UI design. If you want to get hired you need to at least aim for level four. You can also go above level five, itâ€™s not the absolute top, but four and five are definitely a place to be.


Most designers I reviewed were on level 3 â€” almsot there, but not quite. Some were at level 2. There were a handful on level 1.

I paid special attention to levels 4 and 5 though as after just months the majority (88%) of them got their first UI (or graphics design) job.

Dinamik davranÄ±ÅŸ, gerektiÄŸinde yeni iÃ§erik oluÅŸturmak iÃ§in web sayfasÄ± gÃ¶rÃ¼ntÃ¼sÃ¼nÃ¼ gÃ¼ncelleme yeteneÄŸidir. blogList.author: emir aydÄ±n
blogList.title: Deneme BLOG
blogList.content:
Looking at the data and my comments to their portfolios I noticed patterns. Those patterns in turn led to a simple cutoff line being drawn.

You need to be THIS good to get hired.

There are levels of skill to UI design. If you want to get hired you need to at least aim for level four. You can also go above level five, itâ€™s not the absolute top, but four and five are definitely a place to be.


Most designers I reviewed were on level 3 â€” almsot there, but not quite. Some were at level 2. There were a handful on level 1.

I paid special attention to levels 4 and 5 though as after just months the majority (88%) of them got their first UI (or graphics design) job.

Key factors

This breakdown is not about problem solving (unless you count ugly, unreadable UI as a problem â€” which I do). This is about making a UI design that people will find interesting enough to spend more than 8 seconds looking at it.


The main areas of evaluation are:

  • Readability
  • Layout and structure (consistency)
  • Colors and gradients
  • Contrasts
  • Font choices
  • Logical mistakes
  • general sloppiness

level 1 (left) vs level 5 (right)

From level one to level five

There is a stark difference between levels one and five. Mos

blogList.content:
Git Nedir?

Git bir versiyon kontrol sistemidir.


Versiyon kontrol sistemi (Version Control System) bir proje Ã¼zerinde yaptÄ±ÄŸÄ±mÄ±z deÄŸiÅŸiklikleri adÄ±m adÄ±m kaydeden ve isterseniz bunu internet Ã¼zerinde depoda (repository) saklamamÄ±zÄ± ve yÃ¶netmemizi saÄŸlayan bir sistemdir. AyrÄ±ca Git bir daÄŸÄ±nÄ±k (distributed) versiyon kontrol sistemi olduÄŸu iÃ§in her bir istemci (client) sadece dosyalarÄ±n en son anlÄ±k gÃ¶rÃ¼ntÃ¼sÃ¼nÃ¼ kontrol etmekle kalmaz, aynÄ± zamanda tam geÃ§miÅŸi de dahil olmak Ã¼zere depoyu tamamen kopyalar. Her clone gerÃ§ekten tÃ¼m verilerin tam bir yedeÄŸidir. BÃ¶ylece, herhangi bir sunucu Ã¶lÃ¼rse ve bu sistemler bu sunucu aracÄ±lÄ±ÄŸÄ±yla iÅŸbirliÄŸi yapÄ±yorsa, istemci depolarÄ±ndan herhangi biri geri yÃ¼klemek iÃ§in sunucuya kopyalanabilir. Bu nedenle daÄŸÄ±nÄ±k bir versiyon kontrol sistemi olan Gitâ€™i kullanmak projemiz iÃ§in oldukÃ§a gÃ¼venlidir.

Github ise versiyon kontrol sistemi iÃ§in uzak bir depolama sistemidir. Git ve Github aynÄ± deÄŸildir.

Git Komut Ve Ã–zellikleri Nelerdir?

BÃ¼tÃ¼n Git iÅŸlemlerimde kullanÄ±lacak kullanÄ±cÄ± adÄ± oluÅŸturur. (Bir defa

yapÄ±lÄ±r.)


git config --global user.name "kullaniciadÄ±"

BÃ¼tÃ¼n Git iÅŸlemlerinde kullanÄ±lacak kullanÄ±cÄ± mail adresini

oluÅŸturur.(Bir defa yapÄ±lÄ±r.)

git config â€” global user.email eposta@adresi.org
Git init


BulunduÄŸunuz dizini veya istediÄŸiniz dizin iÃ§erisindeki projenizi git init komutunu terminale yazarak .git uzantÄ±lÄ± depo haline getirir.

git init
Git clone


Bu komut, mevcut bir URLâ€™den bir havuz elde etmek iÃ§in kullanÄ±lÄ±r.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

git clone [url]
git add


Repoya(bulut tabanlÄ± depo) bir dosya eklemek iÃ§in kullanÄ±lÄ±r.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

git add [dosya-adi]
git commit


Bu komut, dosyayÄ± sÃ¼rÃ¼m geÃ§miÅŸinde kalÄ±cÄ± olarak kaydeder veya anlÄ±k gÃ¶rÃ¼ntÃ¼ler.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

git commit -m â€œ[Commit mesajÄ±nÄ±z]â€

Bu komut, henÃ¼z aÅŸamalÄ± olmayan dosya farklÄ±lÄ±klarÄ±nÄ± gÃ¶sterir.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

git diff

Bu komut dosyanÄ±n aÅŸamasÄ±nÄ± kaldÄ±rÄ±r, ancak dosya iÃ§eriÄŸini korur.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

git reset [dosya-adi]
git status


Bu komut, iÅŸlenmesi gereken tÃ¼m dosyalarÄ± listeler.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

git status

Bu komut, dosyayÄ± Ã§alÄ±ÅŸma dizininizden siler ve silme iÅŸlemini gerÃ§ekleÅŸtirir.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

git rm [dosya-adi]

Bu komut, geÃ§erli dalÄ±n sÃ¼rÃ¼m geÃ§miÅŸini listelemek iÃ§in kullanÄ±lÄ±r.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

git log

Bu komut, belirtilen taahhÃ¼dÃ¼n meta verilerini ve iÃ§erik deÄŸiÅŸikliklerini gÃ¶sterir.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

git show

Bu komut, belirtilen iÅŸleme etiket vermek iÃ§in kullanÄ±lÄ±r.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

Bu komut, geÃ§erli depodaki tÃ¼m yerel dallarÄ± listeler.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

AÅŸaÄŸÄ±daki komut yeni bir dal oluÅŸturur.

Bu komut bir daldan diÄŸerine geÃ§mek iÃ§in kullanÄ±lÄ±r.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

Bu komut, belirtilen dalÄ±n geÃ§miÅŸini geÃ§erli dalla birleÅŸtirir.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

Bu komut, yerel deponuzu uzak sunucuya baÄŸlamak iÃ§in kullanÄ±lÄ±r.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

Bu komut, ana dalÄ±n taahhÃ¼t edilen deÄŸiÅŸikliklerini uzak havuzunuza gÃ¶nderir.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

git push [variable name] master
git pull


Bu komut, uzak sunucudaki deÄŸiÅŸiklikleri Ã§alÄ±ÅŸma dizininize getirir ve birleÅŸtirir.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

Bu komut, deÄŸiÅŸtirilen tÃ¼m izlenen dosyalarÄ± geÃ§ici olarak saklar.

KullanÄ±mÄ±

git stash save

Komutu ile yerel depodaki commit geÃ§miÅŸimizi kronolojik olarak gÃ¶rÃ¼ntÃ¼leyebiliriz.Komutu ile yerel depodaki commit geÃ§miÅŸimizi kronolojik olarak gÃ¶rÃ¼ntÃ¼leyebiliriz.

u promptlara sizin ihtiyacÄ±nÄ±z olanlarÄ± ekleyebilir ya da deÄŸiÅŸtirebilirsiniz. blogList.author: Taha Aydogdu
blogList.title: Web3 vs. Web 3.0: They are NOT the same!
blogList.content:
What?! Wait a secondâ€¦ Web3 and Web 3.0, ainâ€™t they the same?!

What Iâ€™m going to demystify today is probably one of the most common misconceptions in the blockchain and crypto space. Including myself, only until recently, thanks to one of my students on Udemy who pointed out to me that I had misused this term in one of my masterclasses, I would not have known about this. Read on if you donâ€™t want to make the same mistake as I did!

If you search â€˜Web3â€™ on Wikipedia, this is what youâ€™ll find in the very first sentence of the article:

â€œThis article is about the concept of a World Wide Web based on public blockchains. For the concept based around machine-readability, also called Web 3.0, see Semantic Web.â€

You see, even Wikipedia notices this common confusion among most people. Web3 and Web 3.0 are NOT the same.

Web3 and Web 3.0, even though they are both visions of how the Web will ideally be evolved in the future and both are attempting to fix the problems of the current Web, they are fundamentally different.

To put it in simple terms, Web3 refers to the decentralized and blockchain-based web, while Web 3.0 refers to the linked or semantic web. Letâ€™s break them down a bit further.

Web3

To understand Web3, we need to first understand Web1 and 2.


Web1- is the initial version of the internet, where everything was read-only and static with zero interaction.

Web2- it is what the current web is. It refers to the read-and-write version of the internet, where users can create content and share them, other than read-only. This creates a much more interactive version of the internet.

However, there is this dark side of Web2 â€” centralization. Several giants, such as Google and Facebook actually own and control the data of their users, and they use these data to manipulate users in somewhat unethical ways. Users basically have no control over the ownership of their identity, data and the content they have created.

Here comes Web3. Web3 is tempting to solve this centralization problem by introducing the idea of Read, Write and Own. I talk a lot about Web3 here.

The term â€˜Web3â€™, was coined in 2014 by Gavin Wood, who is the Ethereum co-founder and Polkadot founder. The core idea behind Web3, is to fight against the current centralized dominance and power of the giants, and return the power of ownership back to the users.

But how? Through a decentralized online ecosystem by the implementation of blockchain. The vision of Web3 is to let the users be in total control of their identity, data, and the content they create, and they can decide who can access this information and who cannot. This can be achieved through the use of decentralized data storage powered by blockchain technologies and self-sovereign identity in a community-driven setting, such as DAOs (Decentralized Autonomous Organizations â€” to learn about DAOs, check DAO 101, How to create a DAO in 5 min and this course).

In Web3, you also have ownership on the internet. NFTs, for example, allow us, for the first time in history, to own digital items.
